questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

 

The patient's symptoms – depressive mood, irritability, and worry about the future – began after a clear stressor, which in this case is the loss of his job. While he has some features of depression, the ability to temporarily feel better, such as when seeing movies with friends, makes a major depressive episode less likely.

 

This disorder arises within three months of a particular stressor (e.g., job loss) and resolves within six months after the stressor ends or the individual adapts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Chronic worry is a feature, but there is usually no specific identifiable stressor or precipitant, and the duration of symptoms should be at least 6 months.

 

Option C. Mixed anxiety with depression: This isn’t a specific DSM-5 diagnosis. While the patient has symptoms of both, the clear onset after job loss points more towards adjustment disorder.

 

Option D. Moderate depression: The patient’s ability to still experience pleasure (e.g., enjoying movies) makes a full depressive episode less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute onset of double vision, difficulty walking, and confusion. Given a history of alcohol abuse, what is the most appropriate initial treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intravenous thiamine

 

The patient presents with a triad of symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia (double vision due to paralysis of eye muscles), Ataxia (difficulty walking), and Global confusion (Mnemonic: GOA). These symptoms are characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, a serious condition often associated with chronic alcohol abuse. Wernicke's encephalopathy is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). The most appropriate initial treatment is the administration of intravenous thiamine, which is crucial to prevent progression and potential irreversible damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids with dextrose: Administering dextrose without prior thiamine can exacerbate Wernicke's encephalopathy, as it can precipitate the onset of symptoms in individuals with thiamine deficiency. This makes it an inappropriate initial treatment.

 

Option C. Intravenous lorazepam: Lorazepam is used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms such as seizures and agitation but is not indicated in the acute management of Wernicke's encephalopathy. It does not address the underlying thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Intravenous vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, it is not associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy. Thiamine is the specific treatment required in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion, should be treated immediately with intravenous thiamine to prevent serious neurological damage.

questions.text: All of the following are components of Beck's cognitive theory of depression except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Introjection

 

Introjection is a psychological process where a person unconsciously adopts the ideas or attributes of other people or objects. This is often discussed in psychoanalytic contexts, not cognitive ones.

 

It involves internalizing aspects of others, such as a child internalizing aspects of a lost parent, leading to complex emotional outcomes, which might contribute to the development of depressive feelings.

 

Other Options:

 

Beck's cognitive theory of depression posits that negative thoughts, cognitive distortions, and dysfunctional beliefs are central to the development and maintenance of depression.

 

Option A. Dysfunctional beliefs are ingrained, maladaptive beliefs developed over time, often from childhood experiences, that can trigger depression when activated by stress.

 

Option B. Cognitive distortions are systematic errors in thinking, such as all-or-nothing thinking or overgeneralization, which negatively influence one's perception of reality.

 

Option D. Automatic negative thoughts are recurring negative thoughts that occur spontaneously and contribute to the persistence of depressive symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Introjection is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression; it is associated with psychoanalytic theory, which focuses on internalized feelings towards an object, such as a parent, and is less commonly used in contemporary understanding of depression.

questions.text: A bashful young man who prefers social solitude appears emotionally frigid and lives alone. There is no history of delusions or hallucinations. The most likely explanation is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schizoid personality disorder

 

Schizoid personality disorder is marked by detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals prefer solitude and appear emotionally cold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paranoid personality disorder: It is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others. They may be excessively sensitive and give excessive importance to themselves. The vignette described above does not mention suspiciousness, infact mentions there is no history of delusions. Hence the answer is not paranoid personality disorder.

 

Option C. Antisocial personality disorder: These patients disregard others' rights and frequently violates them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviours such as theft, conning etc. 

 

Option D. Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Otherwise known as Borderline personality disorder. They are almost always in the state of crisis. They have a history of unstable relationships and emotions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by detachment from social relationships and prefer solitary activities. They are emotionally cold and are indifferent to praise or criticism. There is also an absence of close relationships. It is classified as a Cluster A personality disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2152

choices.text: Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents to the ER with confusion and shaking of the entire body. He has a history of excessive alcohol consumption. What is the cause of delirium tremens in an alcoholic? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute infection

 

Delirium tremens is primarily caused by abrupt alcohol cessation in chronic users.

 

Acute infections can exacerbate or precipitate its onset.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fatty liver: Fatty liver doesn't directly precipitate DT.

 

Option C. Gradual withdrawal of alcohol: Gradual withdrawal typically avoids DT.

 

Option D. Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol: Regular small doses wouldn't lead to abrupt cessation symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 572-573.

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long-term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.text: Which of the following is true statement about Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). The most common cause is alcohol misuse, but other conditions that affect nutrition can also lead to Korsakoff syndrome. Its main feature is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory i.e., patients with Korsakoff syndrome can't acquire new information or recall recent events, but long-term memories from before the onset of the illness remain intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia: Refers to Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome and presents with a triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. If left untreated, Wernicke's can progress to Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of long-term memory but intact personality: While long-term memories may be affected in Korsakoff syndrome, it is not a characteristic feature. Personality changes, apathy, and lack of insight can be seen.

 

Option D. Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall: Korsakoff syndrome predominantly affects explicit memory (conscious recall of facts and events), not implicit memory (unconscious memory like skills).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is primarily associated with chronic alcohol misuse. It is characterized by anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) and often retrograde amnesia (loss of past memories). Confabulation is common, where patients fill memory gaps with fabricated information. Treatment involves thiamine replacement and abstaining from alcohol. It often follows or coexists with Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is an acute syndrome requiring immediate thiamine treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 38-40.

questions.text: A drug that selectively reduces the reuptake of serotonin would likely cause which of the following side effects? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sexual dysfunction

 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of drugs that specifically inhibit the reuptake of serotonin. One of the well-documented side effects of SSRIs is sexual dysfunction, which may manifest as decreased libido, delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, or erectile dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Constipation: Some antidepressants, particularly tricyclic antidepressants, can cause constipation, but it's not a primary side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option C. Sialorrhea: This refers to excessive drooling or salivation. It's not typically a side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option D. Visual disturbance: While many drugs can cause visual disturbances, it's not a hallmark side effect of SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1018-1020.

questions.text: Myxoedema Madness most frequently presents as? NEET PG 2017
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Auditory Hallucination and Paranoia

 

Explanation:

 

Myxoedema Madness, also known as Myxedema Psychosis, is a severe manifestation of hypothyroidism that can present with various psychiatric symptoms. It is characterized primarily by auditory hallucinations and paranoia. This psychotic syndrome is often indistinguishable from paranoid schizophrenia, except that it emerges suddenly in patients who had previously exhibited symptoms of depression.

 

Patients with Myxoedema Madness often exhibit a general deterioration in cognitive function, extreme paranoid ideation, and auditory hallucinations. This condition can be particularly challenging to diagnose in elderly patients, where it may be mistaken for senile dementia.

 

Features of Myxoedema Madness:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visual Hallucination and Depression : While visual hallucinations and depression can occur in various psychiatric conditions, they are not the primary features of Myxoedema Madness.

 

Option C. Tactile Hallucination and Paranoia : Tactile hallucinations are less common in Myxoedema Madness, where auditory hallucinations are more typical.

 

Option D. Paranoia and Depression : Although paranoia is a feature of Myxoedema Madness, it is the auditory hallucinations that are more characteristic rather than depression alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxoedema Madness most frequently presents with auditory hallucinations and paranoia, a severe psychiatric manifestation of hypothyroidism.

choices.text: Stop the drug and proceed drug free

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder with previous history of 4 episodes and no episode for the past 1 year, well controlled with 750 mg Lithium, now in the third trimester , comes to the psychiatrist. What is the next step in management ? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease dose

 

Lithium doses may need adjustment during pregnancy due to changes in renal clearance, especially in the third trimester, to minimize toxicity risks while maintaining therapeutic effects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose: Increasing the dose isn't recommended due to increased risk of lithium toxicity in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Switch to valproate: Switching to valproate is not advised due to its high teratogenic risk, especially for neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Stop the drug and proceed drug free: Stopping lithium abruptly can lead to a high risk of relapse in bipolar disorder; it's important to manage it carefully.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, it's crucial to carefully manage lithium dosage to balance efficacy with safety, avoiding both relapse and toxicity.

choices.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death
There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nicotine substitution therapy? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption.

 

 Acidic beverages can interfere with nicotine gum's absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preferably given by gastrointestinal route: Incorrect. NRT is not given via the gastrointestinal route. Nicotine in NRT is absorbed either through buccal mucosa or skin.

 

Option B. Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death: Incorrect. Varenicline doesn’t come with this black box warning.

 

Option D. Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges: Incorrect. Choice between gum and lozenges depends on individual preference, not blood levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is an effective method to assist in smoking cessation. It is used to relieve craving for tobacco by substituting nicotine in tobacco with nicotine in safer forms. Various preparations include nicotine gums, nicotine lozenges, nicotine patch, nicotine spray and nicotine inhaler. Nicotine gum's absorption can be affected by acidic beverages, so it's advised to avoid them shortly before or while using the gum.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 684.

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.text: A patient of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart but there is no change in her weight after 1 week. Which of the following needs to be done? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal

 

A lack of weight gain in an anorexia nervosa patient adhering to a diet can suggest surreptitious purging behaviors:

 

Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal: This helps in ensuring the patient isn't purging post-meal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-anxiety medication: Anxiety is common in anorexia but doesn't directly address potential purging.

 

Option C. Increase calories: Confirm proper consumption and retention before adjusting calories.

 

Option D. Increase water intake: This won't address the primary concern and may introduce other issues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients with anorexia nervosa who are not gaining weight despite adherence to a meal plan, it's important to first rule out surreptitious purging behaviors. Observing the patient post-meal can help ensure that they are not engaging in behaviors like vomiting or excessive exercise after eating.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 320.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. She is relieved of these symptoms by either walking or moving her legs. Which of the following drugs is used in treating the condition?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gabapentin

 

The symptoms described by the patient are consistent with restless legs syndrome (RLS). Gabapentin, and pregabalin, belong to the alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands and have now become the preferred first-line treatments for many patients with RLS due to their effectiveness and good side effect profile.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Pramipexole: Pramipexole and other dopamine agonists were traditionally first-line agents but can have side effects, including augmentation (worsening of RLS symptoms over time with treatment), which makes them less favorable for long-term management.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is not a standard treatment for RLS.

 

Option D. Iron tablets: Iron tablets may be prescribed if a patient has iron-deficiency anemia, which can exacerbate RLS symptoms. However, they are not the primary treatment for RLS unless this condition is present.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an unpleasant sensation in the legs and an urge to move them, especially at night. It can disrupt sleep and may have secondary causes like iron deficiency. Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin, are first-line treatments.

 

Reference: The Management of Restless Legs Syndrome: An Updated Algorithm Silber, Michael H.Earley, Christopher J. et al. Mayo Clinic Proceedings, Volume 96, Issue 7, 1921 - 1937.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman collapses suddenly after hearing distressing news. What is this phenomenon called? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cataplexy

 

Explanation:

 

Cataplexy is characterized by a sudden, temporary loss of muscle tone, often triggered by strong emotions such as laughter, anger, surprise, or distressing news. This condition is typically associated with narcolepsy and does not involve loss of consciousness. The episodes usually last less than 1-2 minutes. During an episode, the person may collapse or fall but remains fully aware of their surroundings. The mechanism behind cataplexy is believed to be related to the inappropriate activation of the pathways responsible for muscle paralysis during REM sleep.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalepsy: This condition involves a state of immobility and muscular rigidity, where a person maintains a fixed posture for a prolonged period. It is not triggered by emotions and is commonly associated with catatonia.

 

Option C. Catatonia: A behavioral syndrome where a person is unresponsive and maintains an immobile posture, often seen in schizophrenia, mood disorders, and other medical conditions. It is not directly triggered by emotions.

 

Option D. Catathrenia: This refers to expiratory groaning during sleep, a condition unrelated to sudden emotional reactions or muscle tone loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cataplexy is the sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions, often associated with narcolepsy.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is exclusively seen in females? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects brain development and results in severe intellectual and physical disability. It is nearly always seen in females. Males with the genetic mutation for Rett syndrome usually die shortly after birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asperger syndrome: It is a milder variant of autism and can occur in both males and females, although it is more commonly diagnosed in males.

 

Option C. Selective mutism: An anxiety disorder in which a person who is normally capable of speech cannot speak in specific situations or to specific people. It affects both males and females.

 

Option D. Atypical autism: Also known as Pervasive Developmental Disorder - Not Otherwise Specified (PDD-NOS), it can occur in both males and females.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurodevelopmental disorder almost exclusively seen in females. It is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene located on the X chromosome. It is characterized by normal development for the first 6-18 months of life followed by a loss of purposeful hand skills, severe language impairment, and motor abnormalities.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Confabulation
  2. Amnesia
  3. Peripheral neuropathy
  4. Ophthalmoplegia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder most commonly caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). It is often associated with alcohol misuse, but can also be caused by other conditions. The primary features of Korsakoff syndrome include:

 

1. Confabulation: Patients often create false memories or stories to fill in gaps in their memory. These are not intentional lies, but rather attempts to make sense of their memory loss.

 

2. Amnesia: This involves significant memory impairment. Anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) is more prominent than retrograde amnesia (difficulty recalling past memories).

 

3. Peripheral neuropathy: This is also seen in Korsakoff syndrome, involving nerve damage that can cause pain, numbness, or weakness, typically in the hands and feet.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Ophthalmoplegia: This is not a feature of Korsakoff syndrome. Ophthalmoplegia, or paralysis of the eye muscles, is a characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome but is a separate condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy, but not ophthalmoplegia, which is associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a history of urinating in public without having any remorse for it. She also has difficulty in getting motivated and has mild memory deficits. Which of the following lobes may be affected? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal

 

The frontal lobe is responsible for executive functions, social behavior, motivation, and impulse control. Damage to the frontal lobe can result in disinhibited behaviors, such as socially inappropriate actions (e.g., urinating in public without remorse), lack of motivation (apathy), and mild memory impairments. These changes are often seen in conditions affecting the frontal lobe, including frontal lobe syndrome or neurodegenerative diseases. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal Lobe: Primarily responsible for sensation and spatial processing. Lesions here might manifest as sensory deficits or spatial disorientation, rather than the behavioral issues described.

 

Option B. Occipital Lobe: Concerned with vision. Deficits or lesions here primarily manifest as visual disturbances, not behavioral or motivational issues.

 

Option D. Temporal Lobe: Associated with auditory processing, memory, and emotion. Although it does play a role in memory, the other symptoms described are more consistent with frontal lobe dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Frontal Lobe is involved in executive functions, decision-making, motivation, and socially appropriate behavior. Damage can lead to disinhibited behavior, apathy, and memory deficits.

 

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 346-348.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a history of persistent ADHD since age 7, presents with new onset of persistent sadness, loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities, decreased concentration, sleep disturbances, and declining academic performance over the past 3 months. His parents report he has become withdrawn and frequently talks about feeling worthless. What is the most likely comorbid condition developing in this adolescent? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Major Depressive Disorder

 

The presentation suggests the development of Major Depressive Disorder in an adolescent with ADHD because:

 

  1. Presence of core depressive symptoms (sadness, anhedonia)
  2. Neurovegetative symptoms (sleep disturbances)
  3. Cognitive symptoms (poor concentration)
  4. Low self-worth
  5. Functional impairment (academic decline)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This anxiety disorder involves consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in others, which is not present here.

 

Option B. Conduct disorder: While common in ADHD, the symptoms here don't suggest antisocial behavior or violation of rules/rights of others.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: The symptoms don't indicate excessive fear of separation from attachment figures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. ADHD increases risk for multiple comorbidities including depression
  2. Depression in ADHD patients can worsen attention and academic performance
  3. Treatment needs to address both conditions
  4. Regular screening for mood symptoms in ADHD patients is important
  5. Early intervention can prevent functional deterioration

questions.text: A patient, who consumed a large number of TCA pills during a depressive episode, presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG. What is the next best step in treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NAHCO3

 

A patient presenting with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG following an overdose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) requires immediate treatment to address the cardiotoxic effects of the overdose. The best next step in this scenario is the administration of intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate (NAHCO3). Sodium Bicarbonate is used to treat the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs, which is responsible for the wide QRS complexes. It works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to mitigate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DC Cardioversion: This is generally used for unstable patients with life-threatening arrhythmias. In the case of TCA overdose, the priority is to treat the underlying cause of the arrhythmia (the sodium channel blockade), which is more effectively addressed with sodium bicarbonate.

 

Option B. Start antiarrhythmic drug: The use of antiarrhythmic drugs may be risky in the setting of TCA overdose, as these medications can exacerbate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because there is a clear and specific treatment indicated for this scenario, which is the administration of Sodium Bicarbonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with complaints of confusion and ataxia. Upon examination, nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

 

The presentation of a 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use, who is experiencing confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, and sixth nerve palsy, is highly suggestive of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. This is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the classic triad of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (such as nystagmus and cranial nerve palsies), and ataxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Korsakoff Syndrome: This is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome that often follows Wernicke's Encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and behavioral changes but lacks the acute neurological symptoms such as nystagmus and ataxia seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by delirium, tremors, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability. While confusion is common, the specific neurological findings of nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy are more indicative of Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. De Clerambault Syndrome: Also known as erotomania, this is a delusional disorder characterized by the belief that another person is in love with the individual. It is unrelated to the symptoms presented in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcohol use due to poor nutritional intake and absorption. Treatment include high dose of parenteral thiamine. Ophthalmoplegia responds first to the treatment, ataxia doesnt improve completely in almost 50% of cases.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orgasm

 

This phase involves the release of sexual tension. Premature ejaculation and anorgasmia are disorders of this phase.

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It involves ejaculation that occurs earlier than desired, often with minimal sexual stimulation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Desire: This phase refers to the interest in engaging in sexual activity. Disorders of this phase might manifest as hypoactive sexual desire disorder or sexual aversion disorder.

 

Option B. Arousal: This phase is characterized by physiological changes such as erection in men and vaginal lubrication in women. Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of this phase in men.

 

Option D. Pain: This isn't a phase of the sexual response cycle. However, dyspareunia refers to pain during intercourse and can be a clinical condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It is characterized by a pattern of persistent or recurrent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation before or immediately after the vaginal penetration.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 579.

choices.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activity

questions.text: Key feature of depression? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low mood

 

The most important feature of depression is low mood, also known as sadness of mood.

 

Depression is primarily a mood disorder, and while other symptoms such as sleep disturbances, guilt feelings, negative thoughts, suicidal ideations, anhedonia (loss of interest in pleasurable activities), and loss of appetite may be present, the key defining characteristic remains the persistent low mood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicidal ideations are incorrect as they are not the key feature of depression. While suicidal thoughts may occur in severe cases of depression, they are not the primary defining symptom of the disorder.


Option C. Loss of interest in pleasurable activity, or anhedonia, is incorrect as it is not the most important feature of depression. Although anhedonia is a common symptom in depression, it is not the key defining characteristic of the disorder.

 

Option D. Loss of Appetite is incorrect as it is not the key feature of depression. Changes in appetite, including loss of appetite, can occur in depression but do not represent the core symptom of the disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low mood, or sadness of mood, is the key defining feature of depression, as depression is primarily a mood disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for preventing relapse in an opioid-dependent patient who has completed detoxification and wants to maintain long-term abstinence? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naltrexone

 

Naltrexone is the drug of choice for relapse prevention in patients who have achieved complete detoxification from opioids. As a pure opioid antagonist, it:

 

  • Blocks opioid receptors, preventing any euphoric effects if opioids are used
  • Has no abuse potential
  • Can be given as a once-monthly depot injection (Vivitrol)
  • Does not cause physical dependence
  • Is ideal for motivated patients committed to complete abstinence

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonidine: While useful for managing acute withdrawal symptoms during detoxification, clonidine has no role in preventing relapse or maintaining long-term abstinence from opioids.

 

Option C. Buprenorphine: As a partial opioid agonist, buprenorphine is used in substitution therapy when the goal is harm reduction rather than complete abstinence. It maintains physical dependence and isn't appropriate for patients seeking complete abstinence.

 

Option D. Naloxone: This short-acting opioid antagonist is used primarily for emergency reversal of opioid overdose. Its short duration of action makes it unsuitable for relapse prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naltrexone is the preferred medication for preventing relapse in detoxified opioid-dependent patients committed to complete abstinence, as it blocks opioid effects without causing dependence.

questions.text: A patient’s higher mental functions were being assessed by a psychiatrist. He was asked to serially subtract 7 from 100. Which mental function is being assessed? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Concentration

 

Serial Seven Subtraction Test is used to assess concentration and immediate memory.

 

Concentration is the ability to sustain attention for a longer duration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Judgement: Incorrect, as judgement involves decision-making and reasoning about complex matters, which is not directly assessed by simple arithmetic tasks.

 

Option C. Orientation: Incorrect, orientation refers to awareness of time, place, and person, which is not relevant to the serial subtraction task.

 

Option D. Attention: Incorrect, although attention is required for this task, the specific function being tested is concentration, which is a sustained form of attention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Concentration, the ability to maintain attention on a task over a period of time, is assessed through the Serial Seven Subtraction Test in mental function evaluations.

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine induces this through its effect on renal handling of water by affecting antidiuretic hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rashes: Rashes are more common with carbamazepine due to its propensity to cause allergic skin reactions.

 

Option C. Blood dyscrasias: Blood dyscrasias, including agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, are more associated with carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hepatitis: Hepatitis and other liver dysfunctions are more often linked to carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? (INICET Nov 2022)

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

 

Explanation:

 

a. Low APGAR score: SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.

 

b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.

 

c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.

 

d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of respiratory depression and is suspected of having overdosed on opioids. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Naloxone

 

In a patient presenting with symptoms of respiratory depression suspected to be due to an opioid overdose, the immediate next step in management should be the administration of Naloxone. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioid overdose, particularly life-threatening respiratory depression. It acts quickly and is typically administered intravenously, intramuscularly, or via nasal spray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naltrexone: While Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist, it is used primarily for the long-term management of alcohol and opioid dependence, rather than for the acute reversal of opioid overdose.

 

Option C. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used in the treatment of opioid dependence. It is not suitable for the immediate treatment of opioid overdose and its respiratory depressant effects.

 

Option D. Methadone: Methadone is a long-acting opioid used in the maintenance treatment of opioid dependence and chronic pain management. It is not used for the treatment of acute opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of suspected opioid overdose, particularly with signs of respiratory depression, the administration of Naloxone is the immediate and appropriate intervention. Naloxone acts as an opioid antagonist and can rapidly reverse the life-threatening effects of opioid overdose.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 293.

questions.text: A patient feels that someone is inserting some thoughts in his mind. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delusion of influence

 

The patient's experience of someone inserting thoughts into their mind is best described as thought insertion, a type of delusion where an individual believes that external forces are controlling their thoughts. This phenomenon falls under the category of delusion of influence, where a person feels that their thoughts, feelings, or actions are being controlled or influenced by an external source. This is also known as a passivity phenomenon, where the individual feels passive and controlled by others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nihilistic delusion: This involves a belief that oneself, others, or the world does not exist or is coming to an end. For example, a patient might believe their internal organs are rotten or that the world has stopped.

 

Option C. Othello syndrome: This is a delusional belief of infidelity, where the patient is convinced that their partner is unfaithful.

 

Option D. Delusion of reference: This involves the belief that common elements of the environment are directly related to the individual, such as thinking people are talking about them or that events are directed at them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A delusion of influence involves the belief that an external force is controlling one's thoughts, feelings, or actions. This phenomenon is also known as thought insertion or passivity phenomenon.

questions.text: What is defined as the emotional release and discharge after consciously reliving a painful experience that has been repressed? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abreaction

 

This term specifically refers to the process of bringing repressed traumatic experiences to consciousness, accompanied by the appropriate emotional response, often leading to relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catharsis: This is a broader term for the release of emotional tension and can occur without specifically reliving a traumatic event.

 

Option C. Venting out: This generally means expressing feelings, especially of anger or frustration, but doesn't necessarily imply working through repressed trauma.

 

Option D. Guided relaxation: This involves being led (usually verbally) to a state of relaxation, and is not directly related to processing repressed emotions.

 

Therefore, "abreaction" best describes the conscious reliving of a painful, repressed experience and the subsequent emotional discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In abreaction, an attempt is made to bring the unconscious memories and emotions into conscious awareness using hypnosis, medications and other techniques.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Derailment

 

Formal thought disorders refer to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought, rather than the content of thought.

 

Here, the association between two successive thoughts is disturbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obsession: It refers to recurrent, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts. It's more related to possession than the form of thought.

 

Option C. Delusion: It is a false belief that is unshakeable and cannot be explained on the basis of a person's social and cultural background.It is a disorder of thought content.

 

Option D. Thought insertion: It is the belief that certain of one's thoughts are not one's own, but rather are inserted into one's mind. This is also a possession of thought, not its form.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Formal thought disorders pertain to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought. Derailment, loose associations, neologisms are examples of a formal thought disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 10

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with episodes of loss of consciousness lasting 5-10 minutes. These episodes occur randomly throughout the day and night, with post-ictal confusion. Family members report tongue biting and urinary incontinence. She has no memory of conversations during these episodes. What is the preferred initial treatment? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Valproate

 

This case presents classical features of generalized tonic-clonic seizures:

  • Random occurrence (day/night)
  • Post-ictal confusion
  • Tongue biting
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Amnesia during episodes

 

Valproate is a first-line treatment for primary generalized epilepsy. It's particularly effective in controlling generalized tonic-clonic seizures and has a favorable side effect profile compared to other antiepileptic medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behavioral therapy: This would be appropriate for pseudoseizures/conversion disorder but not for true epileptic seizures, which require pharmacological management due to their neurological origin.

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: While effective for partial seizures, carbamazepine can worsen some types of generalized seizures. It's not the first-line choice for primary generalized epilepsy.

 

Option D. Ketogenic diet: While the ketogenic diet can be effective in drug-resistant epilepsy, it's not the preferred initial treatment. Pharmacological management with anticonvulsants like valproate should be tried first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distinguishing between true seizures and pseudoseizures based on clinical features is crucial for appropriate treatment selection. True seizures require antiepileptic medications, with valproate being the preferred choice for primary generalized epilepsy

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented to the psychiatry OPD and tells that aliens have been speaking to him and telling him to kill his cousins. This has been going on for 7 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schizophrenia

 

Patient is having auditory hallucinations for 7 months which points to a diagnosis of Schizophrenia.

 

According to DSM-5, for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, the total duration of illness should be at least six months.

 

Out of these six months, for at least one month, the patient should have two or more of the following symptoms. At least one of these two symptoms should be (1), (2) or (3):

 

  1. Delusions
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Disorganised speech (which is a result of formal thought disorders)
  4. Disorganised behaviour or catatonic behaviour (symptoms)
  5. Negative symptoms (i.e., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

 

The ICD-11 also uses similar symptom criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia; however, the duration criterion of ICD-11 is one month and not six months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delusional disorder: In Delusional disorder, hallucinations are usually absent. If hallucinations are present, they have the same content as the delusion.

 

Option C. Brief psychotic disorder: If the symptoms would have been for < 1 month, then Brief psychotic disorder would be the diagnosis.

 

Option D. Mania: Mania has following symptoms:

 

  • M - Mood elevation (undue excessive happiness) or irritable mood
  • A - Activity levels increased
  • F - Flight of ideas
  • A - Abnormally increased levels of activity/energy
  • S - Sleep decreased (decreased need for sleep) (e.g. patient feels refreshed after 2 hours of sleep)
  • T - Talkativeness (overtalkativeness)
  • G - Grandiose ideas and increased self-esteem (increased self-confidence, maybe boastful, and may make big claims.
  • D – Distractibility
  • P - Painful consequences (involvement in activities with potentially painful consequences like making foolish investments)

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bell and pad based classical conditioning

 

This is a first-line behavioral treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis. It involves an alarm that sounds when wetness is detected, conditioning the child to awaken and use the toilet.

 

Other Options:

 

The child described seems to have primary nocturnal enuresis, which is common in children and often has no organic cause:

 

Option A. Pharmacotherapy with imipramine: This is an option, but it's usually reserved for cases that don't respond to first-line treatments because of potential side effects.

 

Option B. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: Not typically used as a first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis.

 

Option C. Bladder training: This focuses on delaying micturition during daytime, which is beneficial but not considered as the treatment of choice

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleep related enuresis is defined as voiding of urine at inappropriate places. It is nocturnal in around 80% of cases. The most common cause of bed wetting are psychosocial such as sibling rivalry. The treatment of choice is bed alarms. Drug of choice is desmopressin. Another medication which can be used is imipramine.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: All the following side effects of lithium, likely to occur after 1 year of treatment except- (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tardive Dyskinesia

 

Lithium, a commonly used mood stabilizer, is associated with several side effects that may occur after prolonged treatment. However, tardive dyskinesia is not a typical side effect of lithium.

 

Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements, usually of the face and tongue. It is more commonly associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications, particularly first-generation antipsychotics, and not with lithium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tremors are a common side effect of lithium that may occur after prolonged treatment.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism is a well-known side effect of lithium, which can develop after an extended period of treatment.

 

Option D. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is another potential side effect of lithium that may manifest after a year of treatment. Lithium can affect the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine, leading to excessive thirst and urination (polyuria).

 

Educational Objective:

 

While tremors, hypothyroidism, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are potential side effects of lithium that may occur after a year of treatment, tardive dyskinesia is typically associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications.

choices.text: Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover
Suicide after taking low dose of drug

questions.text: Which of the following best describes paradoxical suicide? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

 

Paradoxical suicide refers to the situation where a patient, who has been depressed and possibly suicidal, begins to show signs of improvement or recovery and then commits suicide. This paradox may occur because as the patient starts to recover, they regain some of their energy and motivation, which they might then use to act on their previously existing suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

About 2/3rd of patients with depression have suicidal ideation and 10-15% die by suicide. Patients with depressive disorders are at increased risk of suicide as they begin to improve and regain the energy needed to plan and carry out a suicide, this is known as Paradoxical suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: A 45-year-old schizophrenic patient was recently started on high-dose haloperidol. Three days later, he developed severe muscle rigidity, hyperthermia (102°F), altered mental status, and autonomic instability. Lab shows elevated CPK. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dantrolene

 

The patient presents with classic features of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS):

  • Hyperthermia
  • Lead-pipe muscle rigidity
  • Altered mental status
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Elevated CPK
  • Temporal association with antipsychotic (haloperidol)

 

Dantrolene is a direct-acting muscle relaxant that decreases calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, effectively treating the severe muscle rigidity and hyperthermia of NMS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyproheptadine: This is the treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome but has no role in NMS as the pathophysiology involves dopamine blockade rather than serotonin excess.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: While useful in treating certain metabolic conditions, L-carnitine has no role in treating NMS, which requires direct intervention to reduce muscle rigidity and hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: This is used as a rescue agent in methotrexate toxicity and has no role in the management of NMS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening reaction to antipsychotics characterized by hyperthermia, rigidity, mental status changes, and autonomic dysfunction. Prompt recognition and treatment with dantrolene is crucial for optimal outcomes.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Support and education

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks.

 

The primary management for postpartum blues is support and education about the condition, emphasizing its transient nature and differentiating it from the more severe postpartum depression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Useful in postpartum depression but not needed for the milder blues.

 

Option B. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for postpartum depression but is not the primary treatment for transient postpartum blues.

 

Option C. Lithium carbonate: Not indicated for postpartum blues or depression; used mainly for bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman considers chopping her fingers; she plots and imagines doing so but never accomplishes it. She claims she feels no shame for having such thoughts. Furthermore, she claims that the ideas are disturbing her and that she is unable to control them. The thoughts can stop with a seizure or gradually fade away on their own. Which of the following is the root of the problem? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Forced thinking

 

The patient is experiencing intrusive thoughts that she recognizes as her own but finds distressing and cannot control. The key detail here that differentiates from classic OCD is that these thoughts can stop with a seizure. This phenomenon is called ‘forced thinking’ which is a form of psychic aura.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thought insertion: Thought insertion refers to the belief that one's thoughts are being placed into their mind by an external force.

 

Option C. Crowding of thoughts: Crowding of thoughts refers to the rapid succession of multiple thoughts, typically seen in conditions like mania.

 

Option D. Obsession: Obsession in the context of OCD does involve intrusive, distressing thoughts, but these wouldn't typically cease with a seizure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Forced thinking is a type of psychic aura which is characterized by recurrent intrusive thoughts, or ideas, which subside on seizure activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 510.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Ganser Syndrome, except? Neet PG 2017
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Verbigeration

 

Explanation:

 

Ganser Syndrome is a rare psychiatric condition characterized by specific dissociative symptoms, often manifesting in a context suggestive of a psychogenic etiology. It is notably associated with giving approximate answers, a phenomenon known as Vorbeireden. This condition can also involve clouding of consciousness, somatic conversion symptoms, and pseudo-hallucinations.

 

Features of Ganser Syndrome:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. Verbigeration : This refers to the stereotyped and often meaningless repetition of words and phrases. It is not a feature of Ganser Syndrome but is seen in conditions such as expressive dysphasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ganser Syndrome is characterized by approximate answers, clouding of consciousness, somatic conversion symptoms, and pseudo-hallucinations, but not by verbigeration.

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a patient has the right to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

The Mental Health Care Act 2017 introduced a provision allowing individuals to specify in advance the manner in which they would like to be cared for and treated in the event they develop a mental illness in the future. This provision is called an "Advance Directive." The advance directive allows a person to specify how they want to be treated, what treatments they don't want, and to nominate a person to be their representative.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department unconscious. On examination, she has pinpoint pupils, bradycardia, hypotension, and shallow breathing. The mother found empty prescription bottles in her room. What is the likely substance? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Morphine

 

The patient presents with classic signs of opioid toxicity:

  • Pinpoint pupils (miosis) - a hallmark sign
  • Respiratory depression (shallow breathing)
  • Cardiovascular depression (bradycardia, hypotension)
  • Decreased level of consciousness These symptoms constitute the classic "opioid triad" of miosis, respiratory depression, and unconsciousness, strongly suggesting morphine toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cocaine: Cocaine causes sympathetic overdrive with tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis, and diaphoresis - the opposite of what is seen here.

 

Option C. Amphetamine: Like cocaine, amphetamines are stimulants causing increased sympathetic activity, resulting in tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis.

 

Option D. Chlordiazepoxide: While benzodiazepine overdose can cause sedation and respiratory depression, it typically does not cause pinpoint pupils, which is pathognomonic of opioid toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognition of the opioid toxidrome (miosis, respiratory depression, and unconsciousness) is crucial for emergency physicians as prompt recognition leads to appropriate management with naloxone.

questions.text: A young patient with acute psychosis is admitted to the hospital. He wakes up and asks for his wife, even though she is in the same room as him. When she is pointed out, he claims that she is not his wife and that she is being impersonated by someone else. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capgras syndrome

 

The described scenario involves the patient's belief that a familiar person, in this case his wife, has been replaced by an imposter. This specific delusion is characteristic of Capgras syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fregoli syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a delusional misidentification syndrome where the patient believes that a familiar persons can change his physical appearance and disguise as a stranger, and that he can take multiple different appearances.

 

Option C. Delusion of subjective doubles: Delusion of subjective doubles refers to the patient's belief that he or she has many doubles who are living life of their own.

 

Option D. Othello syndrome: Othello syndrome pertains to the delusional belief that one's partner is unfaithful.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional misidentification syndromes include Capgras syndrome, Fregoli’s syndrome, syndrome of intermetamorphosis and syndrome of subjective doubles.

 

 

Reference: Sim’s Symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 124-125.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

Twilight (A) refers to a transient, impaired state of consciousness often seen during seizures or certain other medical conditions. Therefore, it matches with Impaired level of consciousness (2).

 

Oneroid state (B) is a term used in psychiatry to describe a dream-like state of consciousness, hence matching with Oneirophrenia (4), which is derived from the words meaning 'dream' and 'mind'.

 

Oligophrenia (C) is an outdated medical term used to describe intellectual disability or subnormal intelligence. Thus, it matches with Subnormal intelligence (1).

 

Paranoid Ideation (D) involves thoughts dominated by ideas of persecution or conspiracy against the individual. This matches with Persecution (3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oneroid state is characterized by a dream-like state resembling Oneirophrenia. Oligophrenia refers to intellectual disability, and Paranoid Ideation is centered on ideas of persecution.

 

Reference: Sim’s symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 39, 40, 132; Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 4599.

questions.text: What is the purpose of using the SCOFF protocol? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eating disorder

 

The SCOFF questionnaire seems highly effective as a screening instrument for detecting eating disorders.

 

SCOFF QUESTIONS

 

  1. Do you make yourself Sick because you feel uncomfortably full?
  2. Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?
  3. Have you recently lost more than One stone in a 3-month period?
  4. Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are too thin?
  5. Would you say that Food dominates your life?

 

*One point for every “yes”; a score of ⩾2 indicates a likely case of anorexia nervosa or bulimia

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient was brought unconscious to the emergency department after binge drinking 3 days ago. His blood glucose is 580 mg/dL, serum osmolality is 320 mOsm/kg, and arterial pH is 7.32. Non-contrast CT is normal. What should be the initial treatment? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal Saline

 

The patient presents with Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS) characterized by:

  • Severe hyperglycemia (>600 mg/dL)
  • Hyperosmolarity (>320 mOsm/kg)
  • Mild acidosis
  • Altered mental status

 

Initial management priority is fluid resuscitation with normal saline because:

  • Corrects severe dehydration
  • Improves tissue perfusion
  • Reduces blood glucose through dilution
  • Restores intravascular volume before insulin therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. I.m thiamine followed by dextrose: While alcoholics need thiamine supplementation, giving dextrose to a severely hyperglycemic patient would worsen the condition and increase osmolar load.

 

Option C. Insulin bolus: Although insulin is necessary, giving it before adequate fluid resuscitation can precipitate cardiovascular collapse due to rapid fluid shifts. Fluid replacement must precede insulin therapy.

 

Option D. 20% dextrose: Giving additional glucose to a patient with severe hyperglycemia would be dangerous and potentially fatal, worsening the hyperosmolar state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS), initial treatment should focus on fluid resuscitation with normal saline before starting insulin therapy, even in alcoholic patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a documented 20-year history of alcohol abuse, consuming approximately 500 ml of alcohol daily, presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of disorientation, sensation of insects crawling on the skin, and severe agitation. Given this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol withdrawal delirium


The patient’s symptoms of disorientation, hallucinations (e.g., sensation of insects crawling on the skin), and severe agitation, particularly in the context of a long history of heavy alcohol use, strongly suggest delirium tremens (DT), which is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal delirium. Although the history does not explicitly mention cessation of alcohol, these symptoms are characteristic of alcohol withdrawal delirium, which typically occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. DT is associated with a disturbance in consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, and often visual hallucinations, but can include auditory or tactile hallucinations as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute alcohol intoxication: This condition is usually characterized by slurred speech, unsteady gait, and impaired judgment. However, it does not typically present with the degree of disorientation, agitation, or hallucinations described in this case.

 

Option C. Alcohol-induced persisting dementia: This condition results from long-term alcohol abuse, leading to permanent cognitive impairment, but it develops gradually over time and does not present acutely with hallucinations and severe agitation.

 

Option D. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: This syndrome is associated with a thiamine deficiency and presents with the classic triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. The symptoms in the question do not match this profile, ruling it out.

 

Educational Objective:


Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that presents with disorientation, hallucinations, and agitation, typically occurring 48-72 hours after the last drink

choices.text: In children, equally among males and females
In adults, equally among males and females
In adults, occurs more in males than in females
In children, occurs more in females than in males

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with sudden-onset blindness for the past 4 hours. However, on history taking, it is noted that she is not concerned about it. However, she is concerned that her mother passed away recently and that she should have spent more time with her. Physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following is true about the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In children, occurs more in females than in males

 

The patient is likely experiencing a conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder. It's characterized by neurological symptoms (such as blindness, paralysis, or seizures) that can't be explained by medical evaluation and are presumably linked to psychological factors. The indifference towards the symptom (e.g., not being concerned about sudden blindness) is termed "la belle indifférence," although this feature is not always present.

 

In pediatric populations, females are more commonly affected than males.

 

Other Others:

 

Option A. In children, equally among males and females: Incorrect. In children, the condition is more common in females.

 

Option B. In adults, equally among males and females: Incorrect. In adults, conversion disorder is more common in females than in males.

 

Option C. In adults, occurs more in males than in females: Incorrect. The disorder is more common in females than in males in both adults and children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Conversion disorder, also known as dissociative neurological symptom disorder, is characterized by neurological symptoms that can't be explained by a medical condition and are believed to arise in response to psychological stressors. The symptoms do not conform with anatomical and physiological principles. The condition is more common in females in both pediatric and adult populations.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 451-467.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text: A patient was started on haloperidol for the treatment of schizophrenia. He develops torticollis, muscle spasm, and trismus. What is the next best step in the management? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give benzhexol

 

The patient is experiencing acute dystonia, a common and early side effect of antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol.

 

Acute dystonia is characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, which can manifest as torticollis (neck muscle spasms), muscle spasms, and trismus (jaw muscle spasms).

 

The drug of choice for treating acute dystonia is an anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine or promethazine. These medications help relieve the muscle spasms quickly and are often administered intramuscularly in acute situations.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease the dose of haloperidol: While this might be considered after the acute episode is managed, it does not address the immediate need to relieve the dystonic symptoms.

 

Option B. Shift from haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is generally reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) and is not the immediate treatment for acute dystonia.

 

Option C. Shift from haloperidol to fluphenazine: Fluphenazine, another typical antipsychotic, can also cause acute dystonia, making this option less effective for immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an early side effect of antipsychotic treatment, is managed by administering an intramuscular anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine to quickly relieve muscle spasms.

choices.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

 

Stress is a broad term that encompasses the body's physical, emotional, and psychological responses to any demand or threat, whether real or perceived.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External stress: It is inaccurate as not all stress arises from external pressure. Personal thoughts, emotions, and internal conflicts can also induce stress.

 

Option B. Muscle tension: It simplifies stress to just "mental tension." While mental tension can be a component of stress, the definition doesn't capture the breadth of physiological and psychological reactions associated with stress.

 

Option D. Internal strain: It refers to the outcome of the stress rather than the cause or process of stress itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stress can be conceptualized as the body's adaptive response to demands or threats. It's not just a psychological phenomenon; it has physiological correlates as well. Stressors can be external (e.g., environmental pressures) or internal (e.g., illness, or undergoing a medical procedure), and they can be short-lived (acute) or long-term (chronic).

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2117

questions.text: What is 'mental retardation' now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM-5? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intellectual disability

 

The term "mental retardation" has historically been used in clinical and diagnostic settings, but it has now been largely replaced due to its potential for stigmatization and pejorative connotations. In the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) by the American Psychiatric Association, the term "mental retardation" has been updated to: Intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder). This term is more respectful and emphasizes the abilities of the individual, rather than just their limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feeble mindedness and option B. Mental subnormality are outdated and non-specific terms that were used in the past.

 

Option D. Intellectually challenged is a non-clinical term that may be used colloquially to describe someone with intellectual disabilities in a more respectful manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's essential to understand that the term "mental retardation" is now outdated and has been replaced with "intellectual disability" in clinical settings, especially according to DSM-5, to ensure respectful and non-stigmatizing communication.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1118-1119.

questions.text: Shelf life of blood in a blood bank in CPDA buffer? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 35 days

 

Explanation:

 

The FDA-approved shelf life of blood stored in CPDA-1 (Citrate-Phosphate-Dextrose with Adenine) buffer is 35 days. This buffer is one of the standard anticoagulant-preservative solutions used in clinical practice. The shelf life or expiration date is determined by the number of red blood cells (RBCs) that survive in the circulation 24 hours after transfusion. A minimum of 70% of stored RBCs must survive in the first 24 hours for the blood to be considered viable.

 

Shelf Life of Blood in Different Buffers:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 21 days: This is the shelf life for blood stored in ACD, CPD, or CP2D buffers.

 

Option B. 30 days: There is no buffer with a standard shelf life of 30 days.

 

Option D. 42 days: This is the shelf life for blood stored in certain additive solutions, not CPDA-1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The shelf life of blood stored in CPDA-1 buffer is 35 days.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after consuming antifreeze in a suicide attempt 2 hours ago. He is conscious but confused. Laboratory results show high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which drug would be most effective as immediate management? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fomepizole

 

In ethylene glycol poisoning (found in antifreeze), fomepizole is the preferred antidote. It works by:

  • Competitively inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Preventing the conversion of ethylene glycol to toxic metabolites (glycolic and oxalic acid)
  • Reducing the formation of toxic metabolites that cause metabolic acidosis and renal failure
  • Being safer and more predictable than traditional ethanol therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lorazepam: While useful in alcohol withdrawal management, lorazepam has no role in treating toxic alcohol ingestion. It doesn't prevent the metabolism of ethylene glycol to its toxic metabolites.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: This is used for long-term management of alcohol dependence to prevent relapse. It has no role in acute toxic alcohol poisoning.

 

Option D. Ethanol: Although ethanol can be used as an alternative antidote by competing for alcohol dehydrogenase, it's considered second-line therapy. Fomepizole is preferred due to its more predictable pharmacokinetics and easier dosing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early recognition and treatment of toxic alcohol ingestion with appropriate antidotes (fomepizole) is crucial to prevent metabolism to toxic products and reduce morbidity and mortality.

questions.text:
What is utilized to establish dependence among the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)

  1. Strong desire to use the drug
  2. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity
  3. Increased tolerance
  4. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

questions.text: A person who chronically consumes alcohol and indulged in binge drinking ten days’ back was brought to the hospital. At the presentation, he was unconscious. His Non-Contrast CT scan was normal. His blood glucose came out to be 49 mg/dL. What treatment should be initiated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) I.m thiamine followed by dextrose
